conclusion: We’re dealing with an ideal gas undergoing a process from state A to state B to state C, as shown in a p-V diagram. Our goal is to find the heat transferred by the gas, given that the temperature at state A is 27°C.
The axes of the diagram are labeled as \( p / \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \) for pressure and \( V / \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \) for volume.
State A: Located at \( (V = 2, p = 1) \). Volume: \( V = 2 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 = 0.002 \, \text{m}^3 \), Pressure: \( p = 1 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} = 100,000 \, \text{Pa} \)
State B: Located at \( (V = 4, p = 2) \). Volume: \( V = 4 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 = 0.004 \, \text{m}^3 \), Pressure: \( p = 2 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} = 200,000 \, \text{Pa} \)
State C: Located at \( (V = 2, p = 3) \). Volume: \( V = 2 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 = 0.002 \, \text{m}^3 \), Pressure: \( p = 3 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} = 300,000 \, \text{Pa} \)

premise: The process goes from A → B → C, forming a triangle on the p-V diagram.
conclusion: Since C returns to the same volume as A, this suggests a cyclic-like process, but we’ll treat it as two distinct processes (A to B and B to C) to compute the heat transfer.

The ideal gas law is \( pV = nRT \), where \( p \) is pressure in Pa, \( V \) is volume in \( \text{m}^3 \), \( n \) is the number of moles, \( R = 8.314 \, \text{J/(mol·K)} \) is the universal gas constant, \( T \) is the temperature in Kelvin.
